Everyone, welcome back to the show. We've got a great guest today who's been making the podcast rounds. Richard Reeves, Richard is a scholar at the Brookings Institution.

And instead it's just focused on looking at the policy and empirically driven outcomes that one could easily articulate are a problem.
A good way of summing up his thought.

Richard Reeves, welcome to the realignment.
Thank you for having me on Marshall.
Yeah, thanks for coming on the show. Let's just start here. Could you set the table by giving us your central argument in of boys and men?

Yeah, the main argument is that following many of the social, cultural and economic changes of recent decades, there are now some areas where it's quite right to worry about boys and men in terms of gender inequality, which is a weird thing to say.
We're so used to thinking of gender inequality running one way, but in areas like education and work and family life, there are reasons to worry now about boys and men.

And we can perhaps dig into some of those specific areas in this conversation, but I think the trend lines are troubling enough, especially for working class boys and men and black boys and men to warrant specific attention on their problems,
and very often not despite being boys and men, but in many cases, because they're boys and men.
And that's a very, very new thought given the history that we've had around gender inequality, but I think the facts to some extent speak for themselves.
And I think we have a, maybe not a political responsibility, but a cultural responsibility to be attentive to the problems of all groups in society.
And even if it feels odd to now turn our attention to some of the problems faced by boys and men.

That's interesting that you separate political responsibility from cultural responsibility, because if I'm thinking of the Broadway, you describe your work, you're a scholar who studies the idea of equality of opportunity, and how that breaks down across our society.
Wouldn't you argue though that we have a political responsibility to ensure that groups have that equal opportunity?
Yeah, it's interesting. I do think I meant something by the distinction, but now you're inviting me to reflect on what I meant by that.

And I suppose in some ways it's a bit of a mark of pessimism on my part about how weather politics is actually meeting some of its cultural responsibilities, but I think there's a role for politics and particularly policy.
I'm a policy wonk.
I think policy matters. I want us to have good policies. And I, and I, and the book is, I'm proud to say, pretty full of policy solutions, rather than just lamentations.
But I think it's not just about politics. And too often we place the responsibility for culture change onto the shoulders of politicians.

And because they're cultural warriors, quite often, it sort of feels like a good fit. But when it comes to how do we talk about masculinity? How do we raise our sons? How do we think about our institutions?
Actually, there are, there are no policies for those. There are, there are, there is no set of policies that can create the new script from the mature masculinity that I think we need.

And I think that this is a societal issue and one that we can't just delegate to policymakers. I think that's what I was getting out with the distinction. I don't want to let politicians off the hook.
But it also don't want to let us off the hook in terms of what we're doing in our communities and our families on this front.

Yeah, and having read the book, I think the way I'd articulate what you're putting out here is this is one of those weird policy political areas where there are specific individual choices because this relates to family.
How you raise your children where this could be implemented. So for example, my younger brother, he is born in June, you know, grew up in the early 90s.

There was a debate that my parents had where they're like, Hey, we could have him be in the tail end of his grade, or because it's June, we could have him wait, hold mature a bit and he'd start school with that next September grade instead.
That's a way that you could think of the mix of there's a cultural choice that you could really think about there. Like, how would you, how would you think about that distinction?

Yes, that's a great way to operationalize it because you could have a policy that says boys, and I propose this boys start school a year later than girls because they develop more slowly than girls, especially in in adolescence and especially those summer born children like a brother and like me, actually.
But it's also something that doesn't necessarily have to happen through a blunt instrument of policy could happen through a cultural change. And it is happening.
I did some reporting on this for the Atlantic and found that in private schools, it's pretty common to effectively have different cut off dates for school entry for boys and girls.
And especially for those younger boys, it's very often the school suggesting they start later. So that isn't a change of policy even at school level.

What it is is just a cultural recognition that everything else equal. Let's treat boys a bit differently to girls here on the grounds of equity properly defined given that they develop somewhat differently and parents can have those conversations to.
And also there's a responsibility not to make it weird to start school year. For it to be okay.
There's a lot of stigma that can attach to certain things. And it's important that we have the cultural shift that support policy changes that sense policy and culture feed off each other.
Policy can help drive culture change, but quite often policies will fail if they're not accompanied by an accommodating culture.

And there are in fact some where there's something similar where there's like a second pre K class that's not exclusively for boys, but disproportionately for boys. So there are there are people experimenting with this.

I'm passing a new federal law to have a delayed start for boys. I'll be like, no, no, no, wait, wait, Mr President. Wait, wait, wait, let's let's try a little few places first. Let's evaluate it.

Even like the conversation my parents had like, you know, Portland, Oregon, liberal environmentalists, they're having that conversation in the 1990s, starting my little brother a little later, maybe or not.
It's where the men come in and you start talking about, well, the gender pay gap and how much is this structural versus person responsibility.
I think folks are not going to have that debate at all when it comes to a two or three year old.
So just break down the differences when you see the problems between boys and men, women and girls.

Yeah, well, I think there's two things. One is there is just a framing issue here. I think just just generally, it's easier to think about the problems of children generally boys and girls as not the result of their own individual actions.

It's harder to say it's individual responsibility. Whereas as soon as you start talking about adults, and this is true of men and women, it's just, it's tougher to have a conversation where you're talking about structural causes.
People start saying, well, if you're 27 and you haven't found a job and you haven't been able to settle, that's kind of on you.
You don't say that about a seven year old.
So I do think that you're right that it's a more comfortable conversation generally.
The second thing is that the gaps are just so huge in education in favor of girls and then women, if we talk about college too, that it's just, there's no controversy about that.
Not necessarily that well known or talked about. I do think there's a role in just getting the facts out there because honestly, even I was startled to learn some of this stuff.
I didn't know that girls have gone past boys in math so strongly in many places.
And so, and how far ahead they were in English. So even some of my priors were surprised by that.
And then the other thing is the third thing is that in the labor market when we get to adults, it just is much more complicated.
So when you talk about something like the gender pay gap or occupational status and so on, it gets quite difficult to tease out cause and effect.
And the main reason we have this big gender pay gap is because women do more raising of children. It's really a parenting pay gap now.
But that's complicated. So why is versus a let's say, darn drapery 1960s boss saying, I'm going to pay you less literally because of your gender.
That's the way to think about the issue in 2022 then.
Correct. And again, it's one of those areas where people's views haven't really caught up with the reality.
Most of the reason for the gender pay gap is not that kind of direct discrimination. I'm not saying there isn't any.
Of course, it's illegal and you'll pay a very heavy price for it legally if it's proved that you have actually paid a woman less for doing the same job as a man.
It's largely about the gender division of labor around child rearing. So women's wages track men's pretty well now through the 20 through their two people's 20s.

It's like a meat you right has hit the as hit the chart essentially. And that's because women are just so much more likely to take time out of the labor market to work part time, etc.

Right. Choices, they're deciding to leave the market and that's how it works.
That's how it works. That's great. And for liberals, liberals don't even get to that point because they don't, they don't like them moving on from discrimination point.
But that's the beginning of the argument. It's not the end of it. It's the beginning. So why is that?

A, why is there such a big gender division of labor around childbearing and B, does the trade off have to be quite as sharp? Do we have to make parents who predominantly women pay such a high economic price or raising their kids?
Those are the really important questions. And I think we can do two things. One is we can have a more and more equal gender division of labor.
But secondly, we can just reduce the price. The parents pay. That's really the conversation we should be having.
But the left too many people on the left are stuck in the old discrimination model.

Because that's more comfortable and too many on the right. So well, as soon as you can prove that it's because the moms and moms game over and ever in a way, no one's actually engaging with the real issue around the gender pay gap, but for very different reasons.
Something I was thinking about because I've also read your book Dream Hoarders is to what degree is this phenomenon of gender a zero sum game?
Because the key thing, why I'm referencing Dream Hoarders, you're saying the upper middle class to overly summarize a complicated book is hoarding opportunity is hoarding the dream.

And I think that's an advantage you get when you preference certain policy outcomes over other outcomes that hurts other people is the scenario we're describing with women and men, girls and boys. Is there a zero sum this to this?
Does one side have to win at the expense of the other?

Generally not. I mean, in my last book Dream Hoarders, there are certain things I focused on and the biggest one probably was something as basic as land and housing and the way in which in particular the upper middle class zone neighborhoods and hoards space,
literally physical space in order to secure access to better schools, tax breaks and so on.
That's why I'm such an enthusiastic yimby because I think the housing market has a lot to answer for in the US and it is rigged by the upper middle class.
So there's a bit of zero sum there. So you do have to actually change your land use regulation so that you can build more houses on that acre of land than you currently do.
And so I think that the person who currently has an acre of land and is surrounded by people with acres of land will lose something.

And the same could be true of gender and those specific circumstances.
But generally one of the good things about most of the things we're really worried about is it's not zero sum.
So I think that's the evidence, for example, that there's the men's wages have dropped because women's have risen men's wages have dropped for reasons independent of why women's have risen.
There is no reason why men's and women's wages can't both rise.
And in terms of absolute numbers, there's no reason why we can't have more boys enrolling in college and doing better in college.
And in fact, men enroll, but then they're much like to drop out.
Right, that's not zero sum. A guy who starts college but doesn't finish has not in some way been sort of squeezed out by the fact that the women are there too.
So generally speaking, we can avoid those zero sum traps in most of the areas I'm talking about.
And last example, say GPA, there's a huge gap in in in high school GPA.
I don't need girls to do worse terms of their GPA for boys to do better or high school grade.
There's fewer girls to graduate high school in order for more boys to graduate high school.
And so generally speaking, these are absolute problems and not relative ones.

Yeah, so I hope that I'm fair to all sides on this issue. I've been clear that I'm happy to be getting some conversation, particularly on the center left.

Christina Hoff Summers, who's endorsed my book as a very well known conservative writer, she had, she wrote the book, the war against boys in 2000.

And so I think that some of the alarm bells have been ringing on the right.
The problem is, and even Christina did this in her earlier work, is there's a sense of we have to go back to go forward.

This is a huge change in human history, because we've had 10,000 years or however many, however you want to count it, where we basically bound women to men through chains of economic dependency.

And so what that does mean is that the question of what about the man?
What are men for is not just a joke anymore.
It's a real question.
And so they're right about that.
What they're profoundly wrong about is thinking we can turn back the clock or that we would want to turn back the clock.
So they come up empty handed when it comes to solutions to go forward, because going forward does mean moving beyond the traditional family form.
It means forming new cultural institutions.

And so the way I characterize this, as I think about it, is that if the left are guilty of turning their back on the problems of boys and men, the right are guilty of wanting to turn back the clock on women and girls.

Let's assume you never have a second, third wave feminist movement.

Well, most of the things that happened as you've just listed, I think, were going to happen anyway, and they were going to they were going to affect disproportionately male jobs in various ways.

Disproportionately hit male jobs pretty hard.

So a little bit.
But I would say by and large, the economic trends we've seen and the shift towards service sector jobs, and away from manufacturing from heavy energy, they were going to happen anyway.

particularly in terms of their brain development. And that's not true. Girls actually develop earlier. So there's just a there's no no controversy about that that just girls brains develop a little bit early, especially in adolescence.
